text: Thanks people I'll be using all of these today <@UJ99RGF7T> I'm liking the framework you use, easy to remember!
If you've got a writer, could they do it? It's fairly easy to use a standard press release template and research a few local news outlets - they're always looking for content anyway.
<@UJ99RGF7T> I've also added a T to your formula for technology

Promised a list and I meant it: <https://www.ryanlaw.me/content-marketing-library>

I didn't want this to be a mega-list of a million different blog posts - there's so much noise in content, so I wanted this to be a concise, carefully curated list of personal favourites.

thanks to everyone for their recommendations!

@Actually, Charles, you should get somebody who's versed in media relations and press releases. I was on the media side for a very long time and bad or irrelevant press releases are abundant and super annoying. I've also headed PR for a very large company. You need somebody who knows how to target and connect with the right media.
That said, I know two freelancer (not me) who are super experienced. One can help with distro and targeting and writing, another can get you just a quick, well-crafted release.

+1 to what <@UN3RHBFBK> is saying. "PR" is such a broad term that can include influencer marketing, backlink strategy, analyst relations, even events. I don't think tech companies do a great job of clarifying what they mean by "PR" so we end up unhappy with the results.

I have become a huge fan of the media relations role. A good media relations person can certainly write a press release, but they think very strategically about who the small subset of journalists are who care about your company. In my experience, repeat coverage is often a much higher quality than a journalist who covers you once -- journalists start asking better questions, putting your story together, they care about you (which is great when the shit hits the fan).

Writing a press release is super easy. Publishing it on the wire is super easy. Representing you business in the best positive light to the media is something special.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: And IMHO, issue press releases without a media relations strategy is a waste of time. A good distro service costs $500-$800 per release and people get really obsessed with press releases and they can end up being HUGE time commitments.

text:
:clapper:I'm running my first interview for a video case study next month :clapper:

I have found so much content on how to shoot a video (I'm working with a videographer), and very little on how to plan the content, ask good questions, and run the interview. So I have a bunch of questions that I would love to hear thoughts on. I'm going to post them all separately so you can reply as a thread to the question.

1. What are some good warmup questions? (or other tips to help people relax before the shoot?)

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: 2. Is it better to share questions with the interviewee in advance? or does that result in responses that feel canned?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: 3. If someone says something smart, but rambling, is it appropriate to ask them to say it again but more concisely? How many times? :joy: I edit written interviews all the time and take a lot of liberties in making people sound more composed than they were in the interview. Video freaks me out because I completely lose this ability.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: 4. What do you do if someone is just painfully awkward on camera?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: 5. Any templates or tips for making sure you get the content you need?  I pretty much know the exact lines I need each person to say, and the question to get it, and how it will fit into the finished piece. Am I over planning? or this just how it's done?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: I thought it would be, but actually found that I got the most "organic" answers when I went off script. The most it feels like a real conversation, the more natural it'll look on camera. Also, my video crew advised interviewees to "restate the question" in their answer."

Thank you both, your answers are extremely helpful. That mirrors what my expectations were, but it's good to hear it from people with experience. We're a B2B SaaS company, so Media Relations and Backlinks are really what we're looking for at this stage. I'd be very open to talking to any freelancers or companies you recommend!
ah! I love that. of course! That's how you get the response that sounds like someone is giving a talk vs. answering a question from an invisible asker.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: This happened to me a lot. The first 20 minutes of the interview were almost useless because people are so unnatural and nervous. I just marked the questions that had good answers but were rambly, and returned to them at the end when they were more warmed up. It's totally natural and expected, and they'll get used to you re-asking similar questions.

I had one person that was brutal. TBH there's often just no fixing it. We did some editing post-production, but the real answer was to just find someone else who more elegantly corroborates what they're saying, and keep their screen time to a minimum

I think a hybrid approach works well — sharing with them in advance is a good idea, so they have time to prepare their answers. But I usually only give them a handful of questions ahead of time, then go "off-script" with the rest of the questions, to get more candid (and often more interesting) responses.
I am nervous about this :slightly_smiling_face: Is there anything I should do to plan for this advance? Or is it just something to be prepared for?

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text:
I think the best warm-up is casual but interested, active  conversation unrelated to the topic at hand. The goal is to build a 1-to-1 rapport with you so they forget about the camera.

Ask them about their weekend, their family, their hobbies, or what led them to their current position - with real, genuine interest. The key is people feel comfortable with familiar stories, and that nearly everyone loves to talk about themselves. Be their curious friend.

I feel it also helps to give them an outline of what to expect, “I’m going to ask you a couple of questions about X, Y or Z, and then we’ll move on and talk about A, B, or C. If I hear something I like I might ask you to repeat yourself, or restate it for me — don’t worry about getting it ‘just right.’ Feel free to start over if you need to, there’s no rush.”

Keep the camera rolling the whole time and minimize how much you look at or fidget with it. Cover the “red light” if there is one.

I realized it's really helpful to get people to tell stories. They're way more animated than they are if its Q A, Q A. Even if its rambly and useless in the beginning, it helps them feel more comfortable later when you get to the good stuff.
That makes sense. For example, I have questions where I want specific data points, and someone likely won't have that ready just off the cuff. So some answers might need prep work.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: I did my first video case study in Jan this year, and have done about 5 since.  I'm no pro, but these were my learnings! Hope they help :slightly_smiling_face:

Agree with Josh's answer above. Something that worked well for me in the past is a "lightning round" of fun or silly (and brief) questions to break the ice. More than anything, it's just about making them feel comfortable early on, so they can relax into the rest of the interview.
<@UMFSZ8JHL> Can you share what those questions were?

text:
<@UJG12DM1V> I dug through my files, but sadly, I didn't bring them with me from my previous employer. That said, the gist was doing some brief research about your interviewee and coming up with a few fun questions.

Like, we interviewed a guy who loved Batman, so we asked something like, "Who played Batman best?" Or, one of our interviewees was known for his awesome beard. We'd ask "Who's your beard role model?" When they give an answer to these kinds of open-ended questions, it gives you an opportunity to banter a little bit—offer a counter-opinion—which helps them feel a bit more at ease.

Worst case, we'd search for 'ice breaker questions' and use some more generic ones, like "teleportation or flying?" or "if you were a vegetable, what vegetable would you be, and why?"
Share the TOPICS before hand and any anecdotes you know you want them to hit. aka "I really want to hear how our service resulted in 2x sales last quarter. Come ready to go into that."

Another thing I struggled with going from words to video: Make sure they start off with a complete thought because you may have to cut the context setting sentence when you edit:
"When we did that it changed everything" vs "When we finally synced our CRM to Slack, it changed everything"
<@UJG12DM1V> -- We change the published date.
How are y'all making gifs from screen videos? I used to upload to giphy but it compresses the heck out of them.

You could try LICEcap for direct screen recording to gif. The results are pretty good quality. Just make sure to check "Use .gif transparency for smaller files" in the settings, so your files aren't huge.
<@UJE5LQ2JC> Thanks! That makes a lot of sense.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs

text: :pray:
All my future blog posts thank you

Sometimes asking again gets you a stiff answer and makes them more self-conscious moving forward. I've found it helpful to say "you just made a few great points I want to dig into" then break it down into more pointed questions to get just what you want out of them again.

Nothing you can do really. Just pay extra close attention to the subjects that get them most animated (leaning forward, smiling, using hands more, twinkle in the eye, talking a little faster) and lean in hard on those if possible, maybe even asking questions you don't really need answered so that they get to spend more time in their comfort zone.

Just keep asking the questions. Also, oftentimes when you ask "would you say xyz?" Please say "xyz". It's kind of funny actually. But it's people, so you just need to relax a bit. Leave some room for magic. Actually, you probably need to relax a lot, cuz they're going to feed off of and reflect your energy.
FYI, I've been a journalist for several years so done hundreds of interviews. Also PR and marketing, and worked on videos where everyone's supposed to look good and say the right thing.
Does anyone offer or hire people with retainers for SEO or content? I can grasp project pricing and hourly, but how do you set boundaries on retainers?
<@UJE5LQ2JC> I use <https://ezgif.com/video-to-gif> - includes tools for cutting / cropping / compressing the resulting GIF, and all for freeeeee

You can do something like a certain number of pieces (however you define it) with a base fee + any overages and just bill in arrears. For example, if someone is paying you a monthly fee for 2 articles, but they also wanted to throw in an ebook one month, just tack the ebook cost onto your base fee.
Okay cool, makes sense. Thanks.
Just be super specific on the deliverables so there's no room for dispute.
Ha :joy: yes I need to relax a lot.  Any tips for that?! I’ve done so many interviews but the pressure of needing to get the exact line right for the camera is a whole other game.
